coredata.dc:title: Efficient photocatalytic H2 production coupling with selective oxidation of aromatic alcohol under carbon neutrality

coredata.dc:description: To achieve high photocatalytic efficiency, photocatalytic synergistic reaction is a research hotspot in the energy field. A series of ZnxCd1-xS are synthesized, and Zn0.3Cd0.7S performs high photocatalytic activity and stability in the CO2 reduction system coupling with selective oxidation of aromatic alcohol. Taking 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol as an example, H2 (784 μmol g−1 h−1) and CO (67 μmol g−1 h−1) are the main reduction products, and the oxidation product is 4-chlorobenzaldehyde with the rate of 908 μmol g−1 h−1. Moreover, the enhanced reasons of photocatalytic performance are considered from the separation of photogenerated charges, surface defect, band structure, CO2 adsorption and so on. This work improves the utilization rate of the photogenerated electrons and holes, and provides a dual-function photocatalytic system for H2 production and organic synthesis under carbon neutrality.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: XRD patterns of ZnS, CdS, 0.3ZCS (a) and a series of ZnxCd1-xS samples (b).
The XPS spectra of CdS and 0.3ZCS: survey spectra (a), high-resolution spectra of Zn (b), Cd (c) and S (d).
The SEM, TEM and high-resolution TEM images of CdS (a, b and c) and 0.3ZCS (d, e and f), and the corresponding EDS mapping of 0.3ZCS (g–j).
The STEM of 0.3ZCS with surface defects (a, b) and without surface defect (c).

(a) Photocatalytic CO2 reduction activity of ZnxCd1-xS samples, (b) H2 production and 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol oxidation of ZnxCd1-xS samples, (c) the selectivity of 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol for ZnxCd1-xS samples, and (d) the redox activity with different reaction time of 0.3ZCS. Reaction condition: catalyst amount, 100 mg; solvent, 90 mL DMF and 10 mL 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol; pressure, 100 mL CO2; reaction time, 5 h; visible light irradiation, 400 nm < λ < 800 nm.
The stability test of 0.3ZCS photocatalyst in the (a) gas reduction and (b) 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol oxidation.
The apparent quantum efficiency (a) and photocatalytic activity in different solvents (b) of 0.3ZCS in gas reduction and 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol oxidation.
Photocatalytic activity of ZnxCd1-xS samples in benzyl alcohol: (a) CO2 reduction, (b) selective photocatalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol, and (c) the selectivity of benzyl alcohol.
The photocatalytic activity of gas reaction (a) and 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol oxidation (b) for 0.3ZCS catalyst with different scavengers added.

The transient photocurrent response (a), electrochemical impedance (b), time-resolved PL spectroscopy (c), EPR spectra (d), BET curses (e) and in situ DRIFTS spectra (f, under dark) of CdS, 0.3ZCS and ZnS.
The DRS spectra (a) of ZnS, 0.3ZCS and CdS, band gap of ZnS (b), 0.3ZCS and CdS (c), and XPS valence-band spectrum of 0.3ZCS (d).
The bang gap position (EVB, ECB and EV) of ZnxCd1-xS with different Zn component.
DFT calculations and DOS of Zn0.3Cd0.7S with VZn (a, b) and without VZn (c, d).
Photocatalytic mechanism of synergistic reaction on 0.3ZCS: CO2 reduction, H2 evolution and oxidation of 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol.
Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analysis of 0.3ZCS with and without VZn.
Photocatalytic performance of 0.3ZCS sample for gas reduction and selective oxidation of aromatic compounds under visible light irradiation.

head.ce:title: Efficient photocatalytic H2 production coupling with selective oxidation of aromatic alcohol under carbon neutrality

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: To achieve high photocatalytic efficiency, photocatalytic synergistic reaction is a research hotspot in the energy field. A series of ZnxCd1-xS are synthesized, and Zn0.3Cd0.7S performs high photocatalytic activity and stability in the CO2 reduction system coupling with selective oxidation of aromatic alcohol. Taking 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol as an example, H2 (784 μmol g−1 h−1) and CO (67 μmol g−1 h−1) are the main reduction products, and the oxidation product is 4-chlorobenzaldehyde with the rate of 908 μmol g−1 h−1. Moreover, the enhanced reasons of photocatalytic performance are considered from the separation of photogenerated charges, surface defect, band structure, CO2 adsorption and so on. This work improves the utilization rate of the photogenerated electrons and holes, and provides a dual-function photocatalytic system for H2 production and organic synthesis under carbon neutrality.

ce:section.ce:para: Photocatalytic synergistic reaction is a research hotspot in the energy and environmental fields [1–3], and many studies have focused on H2 evolution and organic synthesis currently [4–8]. In the process of H2 production, some organic reactions are proceeded at the same time, with alcohols, biomass and acid transformed into fine chemicals [9–11]. This synergistic effect can promote the separation of charge carriers, and organic matters can reduce the Gibbs free energy of H2 evolution [6,12]. However, the photocatalytic efficiency is not too high and needs to improve. Some strategies have been designed from the photocatalyst construction (regulating morphology and surface defect) and reaction improvement (developing new organic reactions and changing the reaction conditions) [13–16]. As is well known, converting CO2 into hydrocarbon fuel, as a promising form of carbon neutrality currently proposed, is also a reduction process [17]. Combined H2 evolution and CO2 reduction together, it may enhance the reduction efficiency in the process of organic synthesis. Although simultaneous reducing H+ and CO2 to produce H2 and hydrocarbon fuel is a novel way of gas reduction [18,19], the product may be complex. How to improve the reduction activity and selectivity of the catalyst is still a problem to be solved.

At present, common single-component catalysts (such as TiO2, ZnO, etc.) have low gas reduction efficiency and need to use sacrificial agents to consume holes [20–22]. Conventional modification and optimization cannot significantly improve their activity [23,24]. Metal sulfides (such as CdS, ZnxCd1-xS and ZnIn2S4, etc.), due to their unique electronic structure and excellent optical properties, have great application prospects in the field of energy and environmental photocatalysis [25–32]. In particular, their proper energy band positions can provide suitable valence band (VB)-conduction band (CB) positions for oxidation and reduction reactions [33–37]. These characteristics make metal sulfides as a good model material for systematically studying the photocatalytic gas reduction and selective oxidation of aromatic alcohol [2,38]. Guo et al. found that under visible light irradiation, CdSe/CdS quantum dots with Se vacancies can convert CO2 into CO with high selectivity (412.8 mmol g−1 h−1, selectivity greater than 96 %), and benzene ethanol can also generate 2, 3-diphenyl-2, 3-butanediol through oxidative coupling (up to 98 %) [39]. Inspired by this work (simultaneous CO2 reduction and aromatic alcohol oxidation), our study intends to use ZnxCd1-xS (ZCS) solid solution as the research object to construct a new multifunctional photocatalytic redox system: gas reduction (H2 production and CO2 reduction) coupling with aromatic alcohol oxidation in one system. Herein, photogenerated holes (h+) selectively oxidize aromatic alcohols to form corresponding carbonyl compounds and protons (H+), and photogenerated electrons (e−) reduce H+ and CO2 to generate H2 and hydrocarbons. This method improves the utilization rate of photogenerated charges, allows electrons and holes to participate in the reaction at the same time, and avoids the waste of holes (causing photocorrosion and poor stability of metal sulfide catalysts). Obviously, this research provides a new method for photocatalytic high-efficiency reduction, solves the problems of low reduction efficiency and complex products, and also opens up a new way for the efficient conversion of solar energy into high-energy-density hydrocarbon.

Aiming at the problems of low efficiency and complex products in the gas reduction process, this work systematically optimizes the preparation conditions of ZnxCd1-xS samples, which can meet many requirements of the photocatalytic synergistic reactions (gas reduction and selective oxidation of aromatic alcohol). As Zn0.3Cd0.7S photocatalyst performs excellent activity and stability under visible light irradiation, the photocatalytic mechanism is explored by the separation and transfer of charge carriers, surface defect, band structure, and adsorption of reaction substrate. Especially, surface defects play important roles in the photocatalytic performance, by considering the adsorption properties and energy band structure. The successful implementation of this work is expected to achieve important breakthroughs, which may provide significant support for the development of high efficiency photocatalysts and in-depth understanding of the photocatalytic synergistic reaction.

The series of ZnxCd1-xS with different proportions were obtained by a simple hydrothermal method. Cd(NO3)∙4H2O, Zn(NO3)∙6H2O and L-cysteine were use as the Cd source, Zn source and S source in the synthesized process, respectively. Firstly, 2x mmol Zn(NO3)∙6H2O (x = 0, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9 and 1), 2(1-x) mmol Cd(NO3)2∙4H2O, 4 mmol of L-cysteine and 60 mL of ionized water were added to 100 mL Teflon lining, and stirred for 1 h to form a white solution. Then, the inner lining was put in a stainless-steel autoclave and heat it at 200 ℃ for 18 h, cooling to room temperature. The obtained product was washed several times by distilled water and ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 ℃ for 10 h. Finally, the target product was synthesized. The prepared ZnxCd1-xS sample is labeled as xZCS, where x represents the theoretical content of Zn based on the feed, taking 0.3ZCS (Zn0.3Cd0.7S) as an example: 0.6 mmol of Zn(NO3)∙6H2O and 1.4 mmol of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O.

To confirm the type of defects (Zn vacancies or S vacancies) and compare the photocatalytic performance, the 0.3ZCS without defects as the reference (0.3ZCS-R, [40]) is prepared, and the synthesized process is shown in Supplementary Material.

The crystal phase, morphology, element analysis, surface defect, photoelectrochemical properties, lifetime of photoexcited electrons, CO2 adsorption, light absorption and theoretical calculation of the samples were respectively investigated, with the details shown in Supplementary Material.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Photocatalytic activity of gas reduction and aromatic alcohol oxidation
ce:section.ce:para: In the CO2 reaction system (MC-SCO2II-AG, Beijing MerryChange Technology Co., Ltd), the activities of prepared catalysts were tested for the photocatalytic gas reduction and selective oxidation of aromatic alcohol. After adding 100 mg of catalyst, 10 mL of aromatic alcohol and 90 mL of DMF to the reactor and mixing, the reactor is connected to the photocatalytic reaction system and vacuumed. When the system pressure is stable, 100 mL CO2 (purity of 99.999 %) was injected into the system as the reaction gas. Then, the dispersion was stirred in a dark state for 30 min to reach the dynamic adsorption/desorption equilibrium, and the light source (xenon lamp, MC-XF300, Beijing) equipped with a UV cut filter (λ > 400 nm) is lit to start the reaction, with the light power density at 89 mW/cm2. In the entire time of photocatalytic process, the reactor temperature is controlled by a circulating condensate device to maintain the temperature at 5 °C. During the reaction, CH4 and CO are detected with FID, with H2 detected with TCD by online gas chromatograph (GC9790Ⅱ, FuLi, China). After the reaction, the amount of aromatic alcohol and other liquid products were detected by another gas chromatography (GC9790Ⅱ, FuLi, China).

The XRD patterns of ZnS and CdS are shown in Fig. 1 a, which can be indexed well to the cubic sphaleritez ZnS (JCPDS Card No. 77-2100) and hexagonal wurtzite CdS (JCPDS Card No. 41-1049) [41], with no impurity peaks observed. The main crystal planes of (111), (220) and (311) are attributed to ZnS, while that of (100), (002), (101), (110), (103) and (201) are ascribed to CdS. In addition, the ZnxCd1-xS (0 < x < 1, Fig. 1b) samples synthesized belong to cadmium zinc sulfide (JCPDS Nos. 40-0836). As Zn amount is small, the diffraction patterns of ZnxCd1-xS are different from ZnS, which are almost identical to CdS. With the Zn amount increasing, the XRD patterns are changed not so much from 0.1ZCS to 0.5ZCS. When the Zn content exceeds x = 0.5, the diffraction peaks of ZnS begin to appear and become obvious, which are highlighted with green color. This indicates that under high Zn content, the separation of ZnS component occurs in the ZnxCd1-xS samples. This is understandable that the doping of Zn in the CdS lattice does occur between ZnS and CdS. The reason may be due to that the electronegativity of Zn2+ and Cd2+ are similar, and the small ionic radius of Zn2+ facilitates the formation of ZnxCd1-xS solid solution (Zn2+ 74 pm vs. Cd2+ 97 pm) [42].

The element composition and chemical valence of the prepared CdS and 0.3ZCS were studied by XPS spectra. Fig. 2 a shows the full XPS spectrum that the prepared CdS is composed of Cd and S elements, in addition to external C and O elements. Meanwhile, 0.3ZCS is composed of Zn, Cd and S elements. The Zn 2p spectrum (Fig. 2b) shows that the two peaks corresponding to Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2 in 0.3ZCS are located at 1021.5 and 1044.6 eV, respectively. For Cd 3d (Fig. 2c), there are two peaks near the binding energies of 404.8 and 411.5 eV, corresponding to Cd 3d5/2 and Cd 3d3/2, respectively. The binding energy and the splitting energy of 6.7 eV are consistent with the reported results of Cd2+, confirming the existence of Cd2+ in CdS and 0.3ZCS [43]. Notably, the binding energies of Cd 3d in CdS and 0.3ZCS samples are almost no changes, which may be attributed to the Zn atoms present in the remaining CdS. Moreover, their binding energy of S 2p3/2 peak (161.2 eV) are almost the same (Fig. 2d). However, the S 2p1/2 peak (162.3 eV for CdS and 162.4 eV for 0.3ZCS, Fig. S1) of 0.3ZCS becomes wider and shows a positive shift of 0.1 eV. The widening of S 2p1/2 in 0.3ZCS may be attributed to the entry of Zn into the CdS crystal lattice [42].

Scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) were used to determine the morphology and microstructure of the powder samples. From the SEM images (Figs. 3 a, d and S2a), the synthesized CdS, 0.3ZCS and ZnS are composed of nanoparticles. The TEM images (Figs. 3b, e and S2b) further show that the size of these particles are varied from 10 to 100 nm. In the high-resolution TEM image, a lattice spacing of 0.336 nm can be observed (Fig. 3c), which proves the high crystalline characteristics of the prepared CdS. Moreover, the lattice spacing corresponds to the (002) crystal surface of CdS. For 0.3ZCS, the nanoparticles are slightly increased with the Zn atom added, and its (101) crystal surface (lattice spacing of 0.312 nm, Fig. 3f) is found. Meanwhile, some crystal defects (labeled with yellow circle) are observed, which may be beneficial for the photocatalytic performance. Furthermore, its element mapping images (Fig. 3g–j) show that the Cd, Zn and S elements are uniformly distributed in the sample. This indicates that Zn0.3Cd0.7S solid solution is formed, which is not a physical mixture of CdS and ZnS.

The photocatalytic activity of ZnxCd1-xS samples was evaluated by the synergistic reaction of gas reduction and aromatic alcohol oxidation under visible light (λ > 400 nm). 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol as an important aromatic alcohol, is used as the main reactant to investigate the photocatalytic performance. With the increase of Zn content (Fig. 5 a), the yield of CO2 reduction first increase and then decrease. CO and CH4 are the main products of CO2 reduction. When the Zn content (x) in ZnxCd1-xS samples is 0.3, the CO2 reduction efficiency reaches the maximum. CO as the only CO2 reduction product, its generated rate can reach 67 μmol g−1 h−1, which is about 100–300 times higher that of pure CdS (0.55 μmol g−1 h−1) and pure ZnS (0.26 μmol g−1 h−1). Besides CO, H2 as another gas product from H+ (oxidizing aromatic alcohols generated) can be detected with the rate of 784 μmol g−1 h−1. A similar trend can be observed from the oxidation of 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol (Fig. 5b), and 0.3ZCS sample has the highest oxidation product. The amount of 4-chlorobenzaldehyde can be reached to 908 μmol g−1 h−1. From the view of material balance, the amount of reduction products (H2 and CO, 851 μmol g−1 h−1) are almost equal to that of oxidation product (4-chlorobenzaldehyde, 908 μmol g−1 h−1), and the slight difference may be due to the gas dissolution. The deep reason is that the number of holes used for oxidation is equivalent to that of electrons consumed. As the oxidation process of 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol to 4-chlorobenzaldehyde needs two holes, H2 obtained from H+ and CO generated from CO2 also need two electrons. Moreover, the selectivity of 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol is over 95 % for the ZnxCd1-xS catalysts, and no other by-products are detected (Fig. 5c). For 0.3ZCS, its selectivity can be achieved to about 99 %. Besides, the redox activity is increased with the reaction time (Fig. 5d). The CO, H2 and 4-chlorobenzaldehyde can reach the amount of 336.2, 3886.1 and 4500.5 μmol g−1 after 5 h reaction.

The stability of 0.3ZCS photocatalyst in the synergistic effect of gas reductions and 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol oxidation are evaluated. After five cycles, the yields of CO and H2 are slightly decreased (Fig. 6 a), possibly due to the disappearance of Zn vacancies in the photocatalytic reaction process. Meanwhile, the 4-chlorobenzaldehyde in the cycle test is also no obvious declining (Fig. 6b), and the overall photocatalyst show a relatively stable photocatalytic performance. In general, surface defect is conducive to the photocatalytic reaction, and will be disappeared after reaction [40]. The detailed change about defect sites before and after reaction is not so clear. Herein, the difference of VZn for 0.3ZCS catalyst is investigated by the STEM and EPR spectra of 0.3ZCS before and after one-cycle reaction, which are shown in Figs. 4, S4 and S5. From the STEM images, the vacancies (Zn atoms) before reaction are missing (Fig. 4), which are occupied by some small molecules (marked with yellow colors in Fig. S4b and c). This result is further confirmed by EPR data, as the vacancy signal of 0.3ZCS decreases after the reaction (Fig. S5). However, the crystal phase of 0.3ZCS are not changed much after one-cycle reaction (XRD patterns, Fig. S6). Thus, the Zn vacancies cannot significantly affect the stability of the ZCS, which enhance the CO2 adsorption and the utilization of photogenerated electrons (discussed below).

Additionally, the apparent quantum efficiencies (AQE) of 0.3ZCS with different products are measured at 400, 420, 450, 500, 550 nm, respectively (Fig. 7 a and Table S1). For CO, H2 and 4-chlorobenzaldehyde, the AQE can respectively reach to 5.62 %, 15.37 % and 18.60 % at 400 nm, which first decrease and then increase with the irradiation wavelength increasing. Furthermore, the photocatalytic efficiency is investigated in different solvents (Fig. 7b). As 0.3ZCS sample has the best catalytic performance, it is chosen to explore the photocatalytic activity in DMF and H2O solution. When DMF is used as the reaction solvent, the yield of CO and H2 can reach 67 μmol g−1 h−1 and 784 μmol g−1 h−1 under the visible light illumination. However, with H2O as the reaction solution, CO and H2 are also detected, and the yield are only 0.33 and 7.22 μmol g−1 h−1 under the same condition, respectively. The selective oxidation product of 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol is 48.47 μmol g−1 h−1, much lower than that of DMF as the solvent (908 μmol g-1 h-1). Therefore, choosing DMF as the reaction solvent is beneficial to improve the photocatalytic performance. This result may be due to that DMF as an organic solvent, can dissolve much more CO2 gas [44,45]. In other words, DMF can improve the effective contact between the catalyst and CO2, enhancing the photocatalytic activity.
C0 is the initial concentration of the reactant; Cr and Ct are the remaining concentrations of the reactant and target product within a certain period of time after the photocatalytic reaction.

Based on the above results, ZnxCd1-xS samples exhibit excellent photocatalytic performance for the gas reduction coupling with the selective oxidation of aromatic alcohol. In order to study the commonality of the ZnxCd1-xS samples, the 0.3ZCS sample is chosen to evaluate the photocatalytic activities for gas reduction in the system of different aromatic alcohols. Besides 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol, 4-bromobenzyl alcohol and benzyl alcohol, 4-fluorobenzyl alcohol, 4-nitrobenzyl alcohol and 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol are also selected to investigate the photocatalytic performance (Table 2). However, they perform not so good activity in synergistic reaction with 4-fluorobenzyl alcohol, 4-nitrobenzyl alcohol and 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol as reaction substrate. For 4-fluorobenzyl alcohol and 4-nitrobenzyl alcohol (F- and NO2- as the electron withdrawing groups on the benzene ring [37]), the lower photocatalytic activity may be due to the CH4 production, as CH4 need more photogenerated electrons and more complex reaction paths than CO and H2. For 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol, CH3O- as the electron donating group on the benzene ring, it increases the conversion difficulty of alcohol to aldehyde.

To investigate the mechanism of photocatalytic synergistic reaction, some active species scavengers are added in the catalyst system, such as CCl4, triethanolamine (TEOA), benzoquinone (BQ) and isopropanol (IPA), which can be respectively used as the capturers of e−, h, superoxide (
O2 −) and hydroxyl radicals (
OH) [1,46]. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the amount of gas products (CO and H2) are dramatically decreased after CCl4 and TEOA addition. However, with the scavengers of BQ and IPA added, the photocatalytic performance of 0.3ZCS have no obvious changes. Meanwhile, in the oxidation process of 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol (Fig. 9b), the photocatalytic activity is largely reduced only after the TEOA addition (the role of h+). In the reduction and oxidation process, h+ both have vital roles. This is due to that h+ first oxidize 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol to generate 4-chlorobenzaldehyde and H+, and then CO2 reacted with H+ can be reduced by e− to form CO or H+ obtain e− to generate H2. Thus, the main reactive species are e− and h+ in the photocatalytic synergistic reaction.

To further explore the mechanism of reaction system, the separation efficiency of photoexcited electron-hole pairs were studied. When the surface of the catalyst is excited by visible light, electrons and holes are generated, among which the photogenerated holes are captured by the hole receptors in the electrolyte, and the photogenerated electrons diffuse to generate photocurrent. From Fig. 10 a, 0.3ZCS produces the largest number of photogenerated electrons among the three sample (0.3ZCS, ZnS and CdS). Meanwhile, 0.3ZCS sample performs a smaller arc radius (Fig. 10b) than that of ZnS and CdS, indicating that it has a higher electrical conductivity and a faster electron-hole migration rate. Moreover, time-resolved photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy was used to verify the charge separation and electron lifetime (Fig. 10c). The lifetimes of the photoexcited electrons for ZnS, CdS and 0.3ZCS samples are 2.17, 5.65 and 6.66 ns, respectively. Based on these data, 0.3ZCS performs higher separation efficiency and longer lifetime of photogenerated charges than CdS and ZnS, which facilitatethe proceeding of synergistic reaction.

Besides the separation efficiency of photoexcited charge carriers, some other important factors affected the photocatalytic activity are considered, for instance, the surface defects, specific surface area, CO2 adsorption and light absorption. When g = 2.0053, the presence of vacancies is detected (Fig. 10d). This indicates that the synergistic reaction of photocatalytic gas reduction and aromatic alcohol oxidation may be enhanced due to the presence of vacancies (VZn for 0.3ZCS and ZnS, and VS for CdS). For ZnS, its wide band gap cannot be excited by visible light. However, ZnS performs some visible-light activity, which may be attributed to the existence of VZn. To compare the photocatalytic performance of our work with other studies (0.3ZCS with and without VZn) [40], the activity of our work is much higher than that of the previous work (Fig. S7). Meanwhile, 0.3ZCS-R were investigated by cyclic tests (Fig. S8), and the stability of 0.3ZCS-R basically remained unchanged after three cycles.

BET specific surface area (BET) of 0.3ZCS, CdS and ZnS samples are measured by N2 adsorption at 77 K. Fig. 10e shows the N2 isotherm adsorption curve of the prepared samples, and the BET specific surface areas of 0.3ZCS, CdS and ZnS are 24.92 m2/g, 13.37 m2/g and 18.25 m2/g, respectively. The specific surface area of 0.3ZCS is larger than that of CdS and ZnS, which is beneficial for the adsorption of CO2 molecules. Due to the rich surface defects and higher specific surface area, 0.3ZCS can better contact and react with CO2, which can improve the photocatalyst activity.

To uncover the adsorption properties of CO2 molecules on the defect surface, in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was utilized to characterize the adsorption modes under dark state with CO2 flow [47]. For 0.3ZCS (Fig. 10f), CO2 induces the formation of CO adsorbed on the Cd atom (CO-Cd at 2078 cm−1), carboxylate [(CO2 −)as at 1732 cm−1 and (VZn-CO2 −)as at 1606 cm−1], monodentate carbonate [(m-CO3 2−)as at 1558 cm−1 and (m-CO3 2−)s at 1505 cm−1], and bidentate carbonate ((b-CO3 2−)s at 1283 cm−1 [48]. This indicates that CO2 is adsorbed on the VZn of 0.3ZCS and forms (CO2 −)as by accepting e− from S2−. Then, CO2 − on the VZn can be converted to CO in the photocatalytic reaction. The CO2 − group as a key intermediate, are more easily formed on the 0.3ZCS surface than that on ZnS and CdS. It should be pointed out that the CO2 − and VZn-CO2 − peaks are not disappeared after 1 h irradiation (Fig. S9). Thus, 0.3ZCS Zn vacancies can not only facilitate the adsorption of CO2 via dangling bonds, but lower the reaction potential of CO2/CO2 − (-1.9 eV), accelerating the whole catalytic reaction rate [32].

The optical properties of the samples were determined by UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrometer (DRS). In Fig. 11 a, it clearly shows the DRS spectra of 0.3ZCS, CdS and ZnS, and these samples can absorb visible light. For ZnS, its band gap and defect band (EV) caused by the Zn vacancies is detected and shown in Fig. 11b at 3.22 eV and 1.89 eV, respectively [49,50]. In Fig. 11c, it is clearly observed that the width of CdS band gap is 1.90 eV. Similarly, the band gap and defect level of 0.3ZCS are at 2.25 eV and 1.28 eV, respectively. Especially, the VB of 0.3ZCS can be calculated at 1.27 eV from the XPS valance-band spectrum in Fig. 11d. By the same method, the band gap position (EVB, ECB and EV) of ZnxCd1-xS with other Zn component are measured (Fig. S10) and summarized in Fig. 12 and Table S2. The Eg gradually increases with the increase of Zn content [38]. The ECB of ZnxCd1-xS are more negative than the potentials of CO2/CO (-0.53 eV) and CO2/CH4 (-0.24 eV), thus CO and CH4 can be generated and become the main products of CO2 reduction. However, the defect band are changed with the Zn amount increased, and no obvious change trend are observed.

In order to further investigate the role of VZn in photocatalytic synergistic reaction of gas reduction and aromatic alcohol oxidation, the electronic properties of 0.3ZCS with and without Zn vacancies were calculated using density functional theory (DFT). As shown in Fig. 13 a, the band gapobtained from VZn-Zn0.3Cd0.7S (0.3ZCS in this work) by calculation is smaller than that of experimental result (2.25 eV). This is a normal situation, resulting from the weakness of the GGA function in DFT calculations [51,52]. Moreover, the band gap of VZn-Zn0.3Cd0.7S (1.9 eV) is smaller than the pure Zn0.3Cd0.7S (2.01 eV, Fig. 13c), which is also consistent with the experimental data (Fig. S11). In the presence of VZn, the band gap of Zn0.3Cd0.7S becomes narrower and the electron densities are increased, which make it easier for electrons transfer and more likely to generate electrons and holes. In order to further study the composition and properties of the band structure, the total DOS and partial DOS are used to explore the electronic characteristics of VZn-Zn0.3Cd0.7S and Zn0.3Cd0.7S. The results are shown in Fig. 13b and d. For these two samples, CB bottom is mainly composed of S 2p, Cd 5 s and Zn 4 s. While for VB upper, it is mainly composed of S 2p.

Based on the experimental and theoretical data, photocatalytic mechanism of synergistic reaction is schemed in Fig. 14 . There are three reactions simultaneously carried out in one system: CO2 reduction, H2 production and aromatic alcohol oxidation. When light illuminates, h+ is produced on the valance band of ZCS, and e− is transferred to the conduction band of ZCS. Without the presence of CO2, a large number of h+ will be created, which oxidize the aromatic alcohols to aromatic aldehydes, resulting in a large amount of H+. H+ then react with e− to from H2. However, with the CO2 addition, ZCS with rich Zn vacancies, can adsorb CO2 molecules to form
CO2 − with the action of e−. This is a slow step, and enhances the e− utilization, resulting to the recombination rate of photogenerated charges decreased. Correspondingly, more h+ and H+ are generated, with the production of aromatic aldehydes and H2 increased. Although it is competitive between CO2 reduction reaction (CO2+ 2H+ +2e−→ CO + H2O) and H2 generation (2H+ + 2e−→ H2), the H2 formation are indeed promoted by CO2 gas. With the CO2 addition, the photocatalytic activity of 0.3ZCS is enhanced about 4 times, as the production rates of H2 and 4-chlorobenzaldehyde are 187 μmol g−1 h−1 and 208 μmol g−1 h−1 without CO2 addition (Fig. S12). Thus, the presence of CO2 can improve the e− utilization, and promote the efficiency of photocatalytic synergistic reaction.

ZnxCd1-xS photocatalysts are synthesized by hydrothermal method, and Zn0.3Cd0.7S with rich Zn vacancies performs excellent photocatalytic activity under visible light irradiation. As Zn0.3Cd0.7S has suitable valence band-conduction band positions, it can oxidize aromatic alcohols to the corresponding aromatic aldehydes coupling with CO2 reduction and H2 production. Moreover, the presence of CO2 can promote the synergistic reaction, which enhances the photocatalytic activity by improving the utilization rate of the photogenerated charges. This work achieves important breakthroughs in carbon neutrality, which provides a significant theoretical and experimental support by simultaneously carrying out photocatalytic H2 evolution, CO2 reduction and aromatic alcohol oxidation in one system.

Jiafang Liu: Experiment, Methodology, Software. Xiuzhen Zheng: Data curation, Writing- Original draft preparation, Writing -review & editing. Lili Pan: Experiment, Methodology. Xianliang Fu, Sujuan Zhang: Methodology, Reviewing. Sugang Meng, Shifu Chen: Writing- Reviewing and Editing.
